moves.1. c4: I have never done well against the Engish opening
moves.1... c5: This is not the normal reply. Black's normal response to c4 is usaully e5 or Nf6.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. g3 Nf6 4. Bg2 e6: I would say this is too timid. Better is e5
moves.5. O-O b6: Creating a unnecessary weakness on c6
moves.8. Bf4 d6 9. dxc5 bxc5: I now have a major weakness on d6
moves.10. Nb5 Qd7 11. Bxd6 O-O-O: I can not take the bishop because of my weakness on the d file.
moves.12. Bf4 a6: If white wants to exchange the queens this early than I am slightly better if the exchange happens on d7. A6 is a nice in-between move that discourages white from removing the queens.
moves.13. Nc3 Bd6: Removing the annoying bishop. This also loosens whites control over  the d file a lot.
moves.14. Bxd6 Qxd6 15. Qxd6 Rxd6 16. Na4 Ne4: the most active defence for defending C5
moves.17. Nh4: An easily made blunder that tips the balance. White is trying to activate his bishop but black has an equalizing blow
moves.17... Nd4: The hanging knight on E4 is easily parried and black now has a slight advantage in the centre. Notice how my peices are working in harmony. In contrast to white's who seem to be off on their individual missions.
moves.19. Kh1 Rhd8: doubling the rooks and activating my remaining peice.
moves.20. Bxe4 Bxe4+ 21. f3 Bd3: I thought about playing Ng6  but I could not see a clear advantage so I played the drawish move.
moves.22. b3 Nxg3+ 23. hxg3 Bxf1 24. Rxf1 Rd6d: for the pawn black has a tempary space advantage. Plus the pawn is easily won back. White's pawn are easy targets
